company.name: Fajilan and Associates, Inc. also d/b/a Statewide Credit Services
company.address: 2690 South White Road, Suite 235, San Jose, California 95148
company.business_description: Statewide contracts with nationwide consumer reporting agencies to obtain consumer reports that it assembles and merges into single 'trimerge reports' containing sensitive consumer information such as credit histories, Social Security numbers, and addresses. The company sells these trimerge reports to mortgage brokers and others to determine consumers' eligibility for credit.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Standards for Safeguards Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V, Subtitle A of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6809; and the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681 et seq.

complaint.factual_background: Fajilan and Associates, Inc., d/b/a Statewide Credit Services, is a consumer reporting agency that assembles and sells trimerge credit reports containing sensitive consumer information. Between October 2006 and November 2007, the company failed to implement reasonable security measures for its online portal and did not verify the security of end user clients' computer systems. As a result, hackers exploited vulnerabilities in the company's and its clients' networks, accessing at least 323 consumer reports without authorization. After the breaches, the company failed to investigate the causes, patch vulnerabilities, or warn other clients of the threats.

counts.title: Violations of the Safeguards Rule
counts.representation: As a financial institution subject to the GLB Act Safeguards Rule, respondents were required to develop a comprehensive written information security program with reasonable safeguards to protect customer information
counts.fact: Respondents failed to implement reasonable security policies and procedures, including: (a) failing to design and implement information safeguards to control risks to customer information; (b) failing to regularly test or monitor the effectiveness of existing controls; (c) failing to evaluate and adjust the security program in light of known risks; and (d) failing to develop, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program
counts.conclusion: Respondents have violated the Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. §§ 314.3, 314.4

counts.title: Violation of FCRA Section 604 - Furnishing Reports Without Permissible Purpose
counts.representation: Consumer reporting agencies are prohibited from furnishing consumer reports except for specified permissible purposes under FCRA Section 604
counts.fact: In multiple instances, respondents furnished consumer reports to hackers that did not have a permissible purpose to obtain a consumer report
counts.conclusion: Respondents have violated Section 604 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b

counts.title: Violation of FCRA Section 607(a) - Failure to Maintain Reasonable Procedures
counts.representation: Consumer reporting agencies must maintain reasonable procedures to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to permissible purposes listed under Section 604
counts.fact: Respondents failed to maintain reasonable procedures to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under Section 604 of the FCRA
counts.conclusion: Respondents have violated Section 607(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(a)

counts.title: Violation of FCRA Section 607(a) - Furnishing Reports with Reasonable Grounds to Believe Improper Use
counts.representation: A consumer reporting agency is prohibited from furnishing a consumer report if it has reasonable grounds for believing the report will not be used for a permissible purpose
counts.fact: In numerous instances, respondents furnished consumer reports under circumstances in which they had reasonable grounds for believing that the reports would not be used for a permissible purpose
counts.conclusion: Respondents have violated Section 607(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(a)

counts.title: Unfair Acts or Practices - FTC Act Section 5(a)
counts.representation: Respondents were obligated to employ reasonable and appropriate measures to secure the personal information they maintain and sell
counts.fact: Respondents have not employed reasonable and appropriate measures to secure the personal information they maintain and sell. This failure has caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that is not offset by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers
counts.conclusion: This practice was, and is, an unfair act or practice in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

definitions.Personal information: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer including, but not limited to: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) a credit card or debit card account number; (g) checking account information, (h) a driver's license, military or state identification number; (i) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number, that is combined with other available data that identifies an individual consumer; or (j) any information that is combined with any of (a) through (i) above.
definitions.Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act or GLB Act: 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6809, as amended, the "Safeguards Rule" or the "Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule" refers to 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V, Subtitle A of the GLB Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6809.
definitions.Financial institution: as defined in Section 509(3)(A) of the GLB Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6809(3)(A).
definitions.Consumer report: as defined in Section 603(d)(1) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(d)(1).
definitions.Corporate respondent: Statewide Credit Services, Inc. and its subsidiaries, divisions, affiliates, successors and assigns. "Individual respondent" means Robert Fajilan. "Respondents" means the Individual respondent and Corporate respondent, individually, collectively, or in any combination.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.

provisions.title: Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program to protect personal information, including designation of responsible employees, risk assessment, safeguards implementation, service provider oversight, and program evaluation.

requirements.description: Establish and implement comprehensive information security program
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that Corporate respondent and any business entity that Individual respondent, Robert Fajilan, controls, directly or indirectly, which collects, maintains, or stores personal information from or about consumers, shall, no later than the date of service of this order, establish and implement, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive information security program that is reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers, including the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information accessible to end users.
requirements.deadline: no later than the date of service

requirements.description: Designate employee(s) to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program
requirements.quoted_text: the designation of an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program;

requirements.description: Identify and assess material internal and external risks to personal information security
requirements.quoted_text: the identification of material internal and external risks to the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information that could result in the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information, and assessment of the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control these risks. At a minimum, this risk assessment should include consideration of risks in each area of relevant operation, including, but not limited to: (1) employee training and management; (2) information systems, including network and software design, access, information processing, storage, transmission, and disposal; and (3) prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or other systems failures;

requirements.description: Design and implement reasonable safeguards with regular testing and monitoring
requirements.quoted_text: the design and implementation of reasonable safeguards to control the risks identified through risk assessment and regular testing or monitoring of the effectiveness of the safeguards' key controls, systems, and procedures;

requirements.description: Select and retain service providers capable of safeguarding personal information and require them by contract to maintain safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: the development and use of reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of appropriately safeguarding personal information they receive from the Corporate respondent or the entity, and requiring service providers by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards;

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust information security program based on testing results and operational changes
requirements.quoted_text: the evaluation and adjustment of respondent's or the entity's information security program in light of the results of the testing and monitoring required by sub-Part C, any material changes to Corporate respondent's or the entity's operations or business arrangements, or any other circumstances that Corporate respondent or the entity know or have reason to know may have a material impact on the effectiveness of their information security program.

provisions.title: Compliance with Safeguards Rule
provisions.summary: Respondents must not violate any provision of the Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314.

requirements.description: Must not violate any provision of the Safeguards Rule
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Corporate respondent and any business entity that Individual respondent, Robert Fajilan controls, directly or indirectly, and their officers, agents, representatives, and employees, shall not, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or other device, violate any provision of the Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314.

provisions.title: FCRA Compliance - Permissible Purpose and Reasonable Procedures
provisions.summary: Respondents must furnish consumer reports only to those with permissible purpose and maintain reasonable procedures to limit furnishing to permissible purposes.

requirements.description: Furnish consumer reports only to those with a permissible purpose under FCRA Section 604
requirements.quoted_text: furnish such consumer report only to those with a permissible purpose as described in Section 604 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b;

requirements.description: Maintain reasonable procedures to limit furnishing consumer reports to permissible purposes
requirements.quoted_text: maintain reasonable procedures to limit the furnishing of such consumer report to those with a permissible purpose and ensure that no consumer report is furnished to any person when there are reasonable grounds to believe that the consumer report will not be used for a permissible purpose, as required by Section 607(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(a).

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from qualified professionals for 20 years, with the initial assessment covering the first 180 days and subsequent assessments covering each 2-year period.

requirements.description: Obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from qualified professionals
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, Corporate respondent and any business entity that Individual respondent, Robert Fajilan, controls, directly or indirectly, which collects, maintains, or stores personal information from or about consumers, shall, in connection with their compliance with Part I of this order, obtain initial and biennial assessments and reports ("Assessments") from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional, who uses procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession.

requirements.description: Complete each assessment within 60 days after the end of the reporting period
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment shall be prepared and completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period to which the Assessment applies by a person qualified as a Certified Information System Security Professional (CISSP) or as a Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA); a person holding Global Information Assurance Certification (GIAC) from the SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute; or a similarly qualified person or organization approved by the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20580.

requirements.description: Provide initial assessment to FTC within 10 days after preparation
requirements.quoted_text: Respondents shall provide the initial Assessment to the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580, within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been prepared.

requirements.description: Retain all subsequent biennial assessments and provide to FTC within 10 days upon request
requirements.quoted_text: All subsequent biennial Assessments shall be retained by respondents until the order is terminated and provided to the Associate Director of Enforcement within ten (10) days after respondents receive such request.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must maintain and make available to the FTC documents relating to compliance, communications with law enforcement, and assessment materials for specified retention periods.

requirements.description: Maintain for 5 years documents relating to compliance that contradict, qualify, or call into question compliance with the order
requirements.quoted_text: for a period of five (5) years, a print or electronic copy of each document relating to compliance, including but not limited to documents, prepared by or on behalf of Corporate respondent or the entity, that contradict, qualify, or call into question Corporate respondent's or the entity's compliance with this order;

requirements.description: Maintain for 5 years copies of all subpoenas and communications with law enforcement relating to consumer reports or personal information
requirements.quoted_text: for a period of five (5) years, copies of all subpoenas and other communications with law enforcement entities or personnel, whether in written or electronic form, if such documents bear in any respect on Corporate respondent's or the entity's collection, maintenance, or furnishing of consumer reports or other personal information of consumers;

requirements.description: Maintain for 3 years after each assessment all materials relied upon to prepare the assessment
requirements.quoted_text: for a period of three (3) years after the date of preparation of each Assessment required under Part IV of this order, all materials relied upon to prepare the Assessment, whether prepared by or on behalf of the Corporate respondent or the entity, including but not limited to all plans, reports, studies, reviews, audits, audit trails, policies, training materials, and assessments, and any other materials relating to the Corporate respondent's or the entity's compliance with Parts I and II of this order, for the compliance period covered by such Assessment.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: For 5 years, respondents must deliver copies of the order to current and future personnel and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days.

requirements.description: Corporate respondent must deliver order to principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, and entities resulting from structural changes
requirements.quoted_text: Corporate respondent must deliver a copy of this Order to (1) all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, (2) all employees, agents and representatives who engage in conduct related to the subject matter of the Order, and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Part VIII. For current personnel, delivery shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order. For new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to them assuming their responsibilities. For any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Part VIII, delivery shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure.

requirements.description: Individual respondent must deliver order to personnel of businesses he controls that collect personal information
requirements.quoted_text: For any business that Individual respondent, Robert Fajilan, controls, directly or indirectly, which collects, maintains, or stores personal information from or about consumers, Individual respondent must deliver a copy of this Order to (1) all principals, officers, directors, and managers of that business, (2) all employees, agents, and representatives of that business who engage in conduct related to the subject matter of the Order, and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Part VII. For current personnel, delivery shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order. For new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to them assuming their responsibilities. For any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Part VII, delivery shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure.

requirements.description: Individual respondent must deliver order to principals and managers of businesses where he has security policy responsibilities
requirements.quoted_text: For any business that collects, maintains, or stores personal information from or about consumers, where Individual respondent, Robert Fajilan, is not a controlling person of the business, but he otherwise has responsibility, in whole or in part, for developing or overseeing the implementation of policies and procedures to protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers by the business, Individual respondent must deliver a copy of this Order to all principals and managers of such business before engaging in such conduct.

requirements.description: Secure signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt from all persons receiving the order
requirements.quoted_text: Respondents must secure a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of this Order, within thirty (30) days of delivery, from all persons receiving a copy of the Order pursuant to this section.

provisions.title: Individual Respondent Notification Requirements
provisions.summary: For 10 years, individual respondent Fajilan must notify the FTC within 10 days of changes in residence, business or employment status, or name.

requirements.description: Notify FTC within 10 days of changes in residence, mailing address, or telephone numbers
requirements.quoted_text: Any changes in Individual respondent's residence, mailing address, and or telephone numbers, within ten (10) days of such a change;

requirements.description: Notify FTC within 10 days of changes in business or employment status or ownership
requirements.quoted_text: Any changes in Individual respondent's business or employment status (including self-employment), and any changes in his ownership in any business entity, within ten (10) days of such a change. Such notice shall include the name and address of each business that respondent is affiliated with, employed by, created or forms, or performs services for; a detailed description of the nature of the business or employment; and a detailed description of the respondent's duties and responsibilities in connection with such business or employment;

requirements.description: Notify FTC within 10 days of changes in name or use of aliases or fictitious names
requirements.quoted_text: Any changes in Individual respondent's name or use of any aliases or fictitious names, including "doing business as" names.

provisions.title: Corporate Changes Notification
provisions.summary: Corporate respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, bankruptcy, or name changes.

requirements.description: Notify FTC at least 30 days prior to corporate changes affecting compliance obligations
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Corporate respondent shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the corporation that may affect compliance obligations arising under this order, including, but not limited to, a dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this Order; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address.

requirements.description: Notify FTC as soon as practicable if learning of corporate change less than 30 days before it occurs
requirements.quoted_text: Provided, however, that with respect to any proposed change in the corporation about which Corporate respondent learns less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, Corporate respondent shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of the order and submit additional reports within 10 days upon request.

requirements.description: File initial compliance report within 60 days of service
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Corporate respondent, and its successors and assigns, and Individual respondent Robert Fajilan, within sixty (60) days after the date of service of this order, shall file with the Commission a true and accurate report, in writing, setting forth in detail the manner and form of their own compliance with this order.

requirements.description: Submit additional compliance reports within 10 days of written notice from FTC
requirements.quoted_text: Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a representative of the Commission, they shall submit additional true and accurate written reports.

provisions.title: Order Termination
provisions.summary: The order will terminate on August 17, 2031, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging violation of the order, whichever is later.

requirements.description: Order terminates on specified date or 20 years from most recent complaint filing
requirements.quoted_text: This order will terminate on August 17, 2031, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. any Part in this order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. this order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. this order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part.

duration.termination_text: This order will terminate on August 17, 2031, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. any Part in this order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. this order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. this order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part. Provided, further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that respondents did not violate any provision of the order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the order will terminate according to this Part as though the complaint had never been filed, except that the order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.

source_files.order: 08.11, Fajilan and Associates, Inc., also dba Statewide Credit Services Order.pdf
